message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the patient may have amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Riluzole is the only FDA-approved drug for slowing the progression of ALS. Amantadine is used to treat Parkinson’s disease, not ALS. Beta interferon is used to treat multiple sclerosis, and reserpine is used for hypertension but has no effect on ALS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the patient has motor neuron disease or ALS. Among the options, Riluzole is the only medication approved by the FDA for the treatment of ALS, and it has been shown to slow the progression of symptoms.

Riluzole is currently the only FDA-approved medication for ALS and has been shown to slow the progression of the disease. The other options are not indicated for ALS.

Riluzole is the only medication approved to slow the progression of ALS, while the other options are used in other conditions such as multiple sclerosis or Parkinson's disease.

Riluzole is the only drug approved by the FDA to slow the progression of ALS. Amantadine is used for Parkinson’s disease and beta interferon is used for multiple sclerosis. Reserpine is a blood pressure medication and is not indicated for ALS.

Riluzole is the only drug approved by the FDA for the treatment of ALS and has been shown to slow the progression of the disease. Amantadine and beta interferon are not used for the treatment of ALS, and reserpine is a medication used to treat hypertension, which the patient already takes hydrochlorothiazide for.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of dysphagia, trouble writing, atrophy of the right hand, slow speech, and abnormal reflexes all suggest ALS. Riluzole has been shown to slow the progression of ALS. Among the other options, amantadine is used for Parkinson’s disease, beta interferon for multiple sclerosis, and reserpine for hypertension.
